The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m., a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: An English engineer who was lately in India has been attached to the Ministry of Public Works for remodelling the sewage system in Cairo.

div.p: We are asked to contradict the report as to the intention of the military authorities to mount a guard at the G.O.C.’s residence at Kasr el Doubara.

div.head: Pro Russia.
div.p: A benefit performance of Le Maitre des Forges ("The Ironmaster”) will be given by the Gardet oompany at the Esbekieh Theatre on Tuesday next, in aid of the Pro-Russia Society.

div.head: “The Future of Egypt.”
div.p: On August 2ft, 1985. Mr. Douglas Sladen left London as special correspondent of “The Tribune” to visit Egypt and other Oriental countries. His first article is to be “The Future of Egypt.”

div.head: Ancient Egyptian Slot Machine
div.p: Someone has discovered a penny-in the- slot machine in Egypt 2,000 year old. We are n iw awaiting the translation of an inscription describing what happened when an early Egyptian Hmoker who wanted matches got almond rock.

div.head: Legislative Council
div.p: Abdel Hamid Pasha Sidik, president of the Legislative Council, and Hussein Bey Yosri, secretary, had a long interview with Mr. Macbell at the Ministry of the Interior the day before yesterday. The Coancil will m^et on the 29th inst.

div.head: The Virgin of Denishwai
div.p: That remarkable Arabic novel, “The Virgin of Denishwai, has been such a success that the author, Mahmoud Taher H&cky, has do cided to devote himself to a literary and j -urnshstic career, and will shortly become editor in-chief of a weekly review.

div.head: A Fatal Error
div.p: Last night, an Italian residing in the Labbane quarter, Dipari Shinto by name, shot hiR wife’s sister dead in his house, where she had been living. The murderer was arrested, and on being interrogated as t j the motive of his crime stated that he had unfortunately mistaken the poor woman for a burglar.

div.head: Ruining the Creek Court
div.p: in the Hobenlohe revelations it is stated that on October 26, D»9, Prince Hobenlohe dined with the Empress Augusta Victoria at Baden. She expressed disapproval of the Emperor travelling about so much, and she regarded as superfluous his Majesty’s visit to Athens, which, Prince Hobenlohe remarks, “I heard from ‘Princess Betsy,’ has ruined the Greek Court.”

div.head: Darwinism at the School of Law
div.p: According to the native Press, the yonng f’opt who raised such a disturbance at the ^ebool of Law at Cairo, by calling in question the claims of the Prophet, is a discip’e of Dai win hy name Nassif Effendi Gindi el Mangabadi. He endeavours to obtain prosel- ytes tc the theory of evolution among his Moslem fellow students. The Nationalist Press intends taking up tba matter as a signal example of the growth of infidelity owing to the British Occupation, bat for which Darwin and Darwinism wonld be unknown to the Egyptians, so their faith wonld rot thereby bave teen unsettled.

div.head: THE SULTAN S RECOVERY.
div.p: HERMAN SPECIALIST LEAVES

BERLIN, October 17. According to information received by the "Frankfort Gazîttb” from Constantinople, Professor Bier will start to-day for Berlin, the Sultan having quite recovered and being no longer in need of his attention. (Reuter)

The Turkish Embassy in London last week issued the following communication: "The Imperial Ottoman Embassy declares to be absolutely devoid of foundation a sen Rational story lately published in a Paris paper, and reproduced by some English news- papers, in conneotion’with the health of his Imperial Majesty the Sultan.”

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive came to Ras çl Tin from Montszsh this morning, and will return in the evening. Tomorrow his Highness will coma to Ras el Tin, where he will give an "iftar” to the nlema of Alexandria; and after El Isha prayers 4 he Ramadan reception already announced will be he’d.

div.head: LORD CROMER.
div.p: As reported by oar Port Said Correspondent yesterday, Lord Cromer arrived there by the P. and 0. mail boat Osiris. His lordship was weloomei on board by Mohamed Mouheb Bey, Governor of the Suez Canal ; Mr. D A. Cameron, British Consul- General ; Miralai Schalch Bey, Mr. Tarrell, director of Port Said Customs, and Mr. Tweedie, director of the Port Said and Suez Coal Co. Lord Cromer, accompanied by M mheb Bey, Mr. Cameron, and Soha’ch Bey, was oonvayed in a laot-oh of the P irts and Lights Administra- tion to the Quarantine wharf, and went direct to the British Consulate. On his departure by special trair, at eleven o’clock, he was seen off by the local authorities an 1 the British Consul- General, a posse of polioe, under the orders ot an officer, rendering military honours. Lord Cromer arrived at Cairo at 3.40 p.m. He w*8 met at the station by the Advisers and several of the Ministers, the Sirdar and the principal officers of the Army of Occupation and the Egyptian Army, Mr. de C. Findlay and the staff of H B.M.’a Agency, Mansfield Pasha, and many others. His lordship looked in excellent health.

div.head: MK BUCHER DUKRER’S DEATH.
div.p: A few day’s ago we announced the death of Mr. Bucher Durrer, which ocourred on his arrival in Egypt where he had arrived in order to inepeot the progress of the Hotel Semiramis, which he was building at K*sr el Doubra. In the hotel line he was one of the kings of Switzerland, to which position he raised himself from a shepherd by industry, hard work and i intelligence. Handeda of friends among the Swiss and strangers regret bis death. Mr. Bucher Darrer was the "creator” of the summer resort on the Burgenstock. He was the proprietor of dozens of hotels in Europe, j among the best known being the Palace and Europe Hotels at Lucerne, the Sonnenberg at Engelberg, the Grand at Lngano, the Quirinal and Minerva at Rome, the Mediterranean at Pegli, and the Semiramis Hotel at Cairo. He constructed at his own expense many mountain railway lines leading to his hotels, amor g their number being the funiculars to the summits of the Stanserhorn, Burgenstock, San Salvatore, and the heights above Genoa and Lugano. It is stated that Mr.Durrer employed direotly and indirectly a quarter of a million men and women. It speaks volumes for his character that his employés all sinoerely deplore his death. He was seventy two years of age and leaves a large family to carry on his work.

div.head: LAUNCH OF A NILE STEAMER.
div.p: The first tourist steamer of the Nile Express Company was launched at 4 o’clock yesterday afternoon at the Babr el Ama workihops near the Pont des Anglais, Cairo. The ceremony was largely attended, the vrssel being christen- ed by Mis. Shileton, the wife of Mr. V. Shilston, the energetic manager of the Express Company’s works, whose efforts have enabled the Virginia to be put on the water a few weeks after leaving the builders in sections. The Virginia is 150 feet in length with 2J feet beam and will draw only two feet of water, although from keel plate to upper deck she has a depth of 43 feet. Her speed against the stream will amount to twelve knots.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S. S. Assiont left Malta yesterday afternoon, and is due at Alexandria on Sunday morning with passenger and mails. The Messageries Maritimes mail boat Porto gal arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yesterday morning.

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE.
div.p: RETURNS FOR SEPTEMBER.

During last month the Egyptian imports showed an increase to the value of L E 121, 822 over the corresponding month of last year, whereas the exports showed a decrease L.E. 19,966. From January 1 to September 30 the excess of imports over the corresponding period of last year was L E. 1,741,777 and of exports L. E. 764,738. England, of course, heads the list with both imports and exports, the values for September being L.E. 632,459 and L. E. £02,613. respectively. Turkish im- ports amounted L.E 308,797, and France follows with L E. 221,019. Austria Hungary imported goods to the value of L.E. 169,995, and Germany comes next with L.E. 124,866. Germany’s exports, however, present a considerable advantage over other Continental countries, her figures therefor being L. E. 91,550, while France’s exports only amounted to L E. 71,205and Austria Hungary’s to L. E. 48.595 against L.E. 56,471 iu September 1905. For the three-quarters of the year England’s increase in imports is L. E 535,6*3, and in exports L. E. 462,738, whereas Germany’s exports show a decrease of L.E. 163.874 and her imports an increase of L.E. 32,962. The export of cotton and material for textile industries between January 1 and September 3 amounted to LE. 10,996,899, being an increase of L E. 1,339,246 over the corresponding period of 19r 5. A decrease of L. E. 271,026 for cereals and L.E. 385,743 for sugar and agricultural produce is reported, and tobacco exports show a decrease of L. E. 28,060. England’s increase in the import of cigarettes for the month of September amounted to 2,947 kilos and for the three-quarters of the year 1,411 kilos., the total import being 63,779 kilos. Germany showed a falling-off of 15,631 kilos, for September and 38,831 for the full period. France imported an increase of 1 050 kilos, in September, her total increase being 2,851 kilos, and Sweden and Norway give the excellent excess over last year of 1,764 kilos, for September and 2,566 over the three- quarten period. The statistics, however, show a falling off in the cigarette trade, the total weight exported from Egypt in September being 11,027 kilos, inferior to September 1905, and the decrease between January 1 and September 30 amounts to 33,831 kilos.

div.head: KHARTOUM REMINISCENCES.
div.p: Dr. Abbate Pasha has recently returned from his holiday in Europe, the greater part of which was spent in Greece and Italy, acd with his return we welcome the appearance of his pamphlet, "Khartoum, Revue après cin quanta ans (1858-1906)” which has been published by the Khédivial Geographical Society, of which he is president. The pamphlet is devoted to the anbjeot of the lecture which be gave to the society last sommer, and which was reported at the time in the "Egyptian Gazette." He brings ont very dearly the | wonderful transformations which have taken place in the Sudan’s capital during the lengthy period under review. The lecture from which I the pamphlet draws its substance was of more than ephemeral interest, and is well-deserving of the permanent record whioh the Khédivial Geographical Sociely has given it.

div.head: UNREST IN EGYPT.
div.p: EXAGGERATION IN EUROPE.

Every year the Riviera, Algeria, and other winter resorts find that Egypt is becoming a more and more serious competitor, and the beauty of the perfect winter weather at Assouan and Luxor are now recognized as far more attractive and beneficial than the on trustworthy climate of Continental resorts. Const quently this season Egypt’s competitors are doing their utmost to raise the score of "Uurest in Egypt,” hoping to frighten away intending visitors to the valley of the Nile by brandishing the bogey of Pan- Islamism and fanaticism throughout the Euro- pean Press. Here for example is a specimen of the alarmist reports, the author being the Malta correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph:’’ Those Maltese, he says, who have connections with Egypt state that it is persistently reported in the bazaars in the towns on the Nile that there is serious unrest, which may become acute at the beginning of next year. The ‘ Express” correspondent at Cairo maintains his former assertion that 420 troops are kept under arms at night in readiness in that oity fur instant service. The reason for this precaution is kept secret by the military authorities. So far sa is known to Europeans an attack by the natives is not threatened. The way every rumour of unrest in this country is exaggerated in Europe is remarkable when contrasted with the comparative silence aboot disturbances elsewhere. If such an out- break as oocnrred a few days ago in Algeria took plaoe here it: would have beeD telegraphed all over Earope. We extraot the inoident from a "Globe” to hand by the Brindisi mail : — "A strange aggression, and one that shows the ntterly nntameable and unreliable disposi- tion of the Arab is reported from Algeria. It took pLce in the Bouira district, about 93 miles from Algiers. A patrol of ten military police ander a lieutenant was patrolling the native settlements of (he region and at about eleven at night reaohed Bouira, when out of the darkness they were assailed by terrible oriea, and a volley of gunshots and stones, besides being attacked with oodgels. The mob numbered about a thousand, and six of the gendarmes were hart before they had quite realised the position. They, however, made determined headway, and Boon drove off the assailants with thair revolvers. Owing to the darkness, however, the enemy could carry oft their fallen, and the police oould make no arrests. Nothing is known as to the motives for the outbreak.”

div.head: ‘ONE OF THE BEST.’
div.p: YOUNG EGYPTIANS AND MR. BLUNT.

“A1 Lewa” publishes the text of a letter addressed recently to Mr. Wilfred Scawen Blunt by a number of Yonng Egyptians, expressing their gratitude to the author for his recent work, "Atrooities of Justice under British Rale in Egypt.” The following is a translation of the letter : — "We have read your pamphlet recently published by the Press, and yonr other state- ments translated by "A1 Lewa,” and are exceedingly glad to think that justice has SQoh strong supporters and heroes who are not afraid of oritioism in speaking the troth. 0 oompassionate man, we greet thee without being acquainted with thee. We greet and shake hands with thee beoaase we find in ihee the man who fears none bat God and his own oonecienoe. We greet thee because those who seek justice aBd troth are few, and those who declare their free bat moderate opinion are fewer still. We greet and thank thee beoaase we see that thoa hast no eqaal among Euro- peans. Thoa wert just in thy writings and right in thy oritioism9 : thoa art numbered among the best of men.”

div.head: KAMEL AND TURKEY.
div.p: A1 Mokattam Constantinople Correspondent irrites that the regular salary which the proprietor of “A1 Lewa” drew from the Turkish Government in consideration of his attacks on Bngland recently came nnder the control of the Finance Ministry and will, therefore, in accord- ance with the custom of that Ministry, only be paid at fitful intervals. Our contemporary adds that this is consid- ered to account for “A1 Lewa’s” waning Z9al for the Ottoman Government. At the time of the Sinai frontier dispute Mustapha Pasha Kamel considered Turkey’s olaims as perfectly valid and jujt. Now he is at paiBB to point out that he has no connection with Turkey and could never countenance her interference in the affairs of this oountiy.

div.head: ROUTE MARCH
div.p: The Inniskilling Dragoons will goon a route march from Cairo through districts of the Delta, visiting Benha, Belbeis, Zagszlg, Sim- bellawein, Mansourab, Tantah, Shebin el Korn, and Asbmoun. The march is expected to last for about nine days. (“Al Mokattam”).

div.head: EGYPT AND BISMARCK.
div.p: PRINCE HOHENLOHE’S INTERESTING REVELATIONS.

Prince Hohenlohe’s Memoirs, the publication ot which has called forth an angry remonstrance from the Kaiser, contain sqme interesting particulars of Prince Bismarck’s attitude towards Egypt. The Memoirs plnnge into the Werdegang of the Dual Alliance by some account of M. Herbe4te, the new Ambassador in Berlin (1886), who is deeoribed as thinking that be oould represent a rapproche- ment between Franoe and Russia as something quite harmless from the German point of view. Herbette, Prince Hohenlohe learned from Biilow, the Prussian Minister at Baden, also wanted to get Germany to aot with Franoe in the Egyptian and other questions against England, but Biamarok ‘ thought that Franoe was too uncertain an ally to make it worth while to quarrel with England. Franoe’s over- tures would, therefore, not be summarily re jeoted, but be treated in a dilatory manner.'* There had previously been a good deal of talk on Bismarck's partaboct the relations of France and Eagland. On October 23, 1881, Bismarck had said to Prince Hohenlohe at Varzin that Germany must wish Franoe every suocess in Africa so that her attention might be drawn away from the Rhine. "So long as Franoe had no allies she ooald not become dangerous for ns. We should be able to beat her even if she had the English on her side.” Again at Varz’n, on November 7, 1882, Bismarck said that only the Monarchy was dangerous in France, that Germany conld always maintain a benevolent attitade towards the Republio, and that she coaid "quietly look on when the English and the Frenoh locomotives anywhere came into collision.” On October 27, 1883, Prinoe Bismarck narrated at Friedriohsrnh that he had recently had a visit from Mnkhtar Pasha, who wanted him to ose his ioflaenoe against British enorochments on Turkey. Bismarck deolined to interfere, and advised Makhtar that "the Turks should apply to Franoe aboat Egypt.” In Bulgaria they should help themselves, and if the English bothered them about Armenia they should envoyer promener the Englinb—a phrase whioh Prinoe Bismarck then paraphrased into a very coarse one. The Tark saw the force of what he said. On this oooasion Bismarck spoke of G’adstone as "an orator, but a stupid fellow.” In August, 1884, Prinoe Hohenlohe gives in a short note the particulars of the Franco-German rapproche- ment nnder the auspices of Ferry. "Ia the West African question there will be common aotion, as likewise with regard to varions Egyptian questions, such as the quarantine, the Suez Canal, the L:qaidation Commission, o.” On November 2, 1884, Prince Hohenlohe had an audience of the old Emperor William, who ‘ spoke of the good relations with Franoe and smiled. He then referred to England, and lamented the Radical tendencies of the Govern- ment and Chamberlain’s purpose of oarrying the Reform Bill by oreating a batch of Peers. This makes him nneasy, and he is afraid that the Republican movement may get the upper hand in England. What would bathe outcome? ‘We shall have hard work keeping our places.’ It was, therefore, necessary that at least the three Empires should unite to defend the principle of monarchy. That was the cause of the meeting which had taken place at Skisrniewioe. Prince William (the present Emperor, who had gone on a mission of State to St. Petersburg in the previous May) had exercised a very good influence upon the Emperor of Russia. He himself and Bismarck had given the Prince instructions to advocate the anion of the three Imperial Powers, and the Prince had done it very well.” The old Kaiser entreated Prince Hohenlohe with greetings to Ferry, of whom he had a high opinion. "I was to say that we did not desire a quarrel between England and France. Just let Gladstone go on. It is good for as, not for England.”

div.head: THE ITALIANS IN EGYPT.
div.p: A very interesting work has just been completed by Professor L. A.Balboni, of Alexandria, entitled "Gl’Italiani nella Civiltà Egiziana del Seoolo XIX,” (Penasson, publishers). Italy has had considerable influence in Egypt sinoe the fourteenth century, when Venice became the great go between for the trade of the Near East with Earope, and the Italian langaage is still more generally spoken in Egypt than any other Earopean tongae. Professor Balboni conflues his labours to telling of the work of Italy in Egypt during the nineteenth oentury, and his labours have been so thorough that he has been able to oempile a three volume work of over fifteen hundred pages. He begins with the French expedition to Egypt, and takes his readers through the history of the oountry until the most recent times in the first and seoond volnme- The concluding part of the work is devoted to a review of the present oonditions of the Italian oolony, their schools, institutions, oommerce, journals, etc., and ends with an essay on the decline of the use of the Italian langaage in this oountry. The amount of eredition displayed in the work is enormons, and a great many of the facts connected with the work ot the Italians here are not to be obtained in any other work that we know of. The book is well printed and has evidently been most rcrepnlonsly compiled; it will be of great use to everyone who wishes to beoome acquainted with the growth of European influence in the valley of the Nile. We heartily congratnlate Professor Balboni on his magnum opus, and the Italian oolony in Egypt should be proad of possessing saoh an aooomplished and erudite historian.
Mastapha Pasha Fehmy is expeoted to arrive at Alexandria on Monday.
El Lewa F. ThureeysEen Pasha, second equerry to the Khedive, has returned from leave, and is staying at Bacos, Ramleh.

M. Cambon, French Ambassador to Great Britain, who was to have left Marseilles for Egypt last Wednesday, has postponed his departure, and will leave on the 19th inst by the mail boat Equatear for Alexandria.
Bl-Kaimkam Charlton Bey, secretary to the Ministry of War, has returned to Cairo from Europe.
The wife of Mr. J. C. Grew, formerly secretary to the American Diplomatic Agency at Cairo, gave birth to a daughter on the 24th alt at the village of Giverny, France.
Professor Flinders Petrie will deliver the annual Hoxley Memorial leotare at the Anthro- pological Institute on November 1.
Abbé Manrioe Carton de Wiart, a near rela- tive of the eminent Cairo lawyer, has been ap- pointed honorary oanon of Namar Cathedral, Belgium.
The well-known Anglo Greek, Mr. Basil Me- laxas Vagliano, 16, Dawson-plaoe, Bayswater House, Old Broad-street, who died on September 30, left estate valued at £197,224 gross.

Mr. George C. Imbaalt, of the Cleveland Bridge and Engineering Co., Limited, who designed and personally supervised the con- struction of the bridge across the Zimbesi at the Viotoria Falls, is expeoted in Egypt early in December.

Mr. Frederick Nicholsor, the general man- ager of the Sudan Mercantile Co., Limited (London and Port Sudan), has arrived at Port Said en route to Port Sadan. He speaks in glowing terms of the fatare of the Sudan, and the extraordinary zeal and intelligent keenness of the officials who are working to change ohaoa to business-like order.

div.head: DEATH OF GENERAL SIR WILLIAM GALBRAITH.
div.p: London, Ootober 17. Mejor-General Sir William Galbraith, K.C.B., is dead. (RsuUr)

Major-General Sir William Galbraith, who was oreated a Knight Commander of the Bath in 1897 in recognition of his excellent servioes in India, was born in 1837, and was the son of the Rev. John Galbraith, Reotor of Tuam. He received his commission in the 85th King’s Light Infantry in 1855, reached his oaptaincy ten years later, and in 1877 was promoted to the rank ot major. Two years later he was made lientenant-oolonel, in 1883 he became colonel, and ten years after that he was promoted to the rank of major-general. Daring the Afghan war he served as assistant adjutant general and earned the medal with two olasps, and he took a pro- minent part in the Hagara expedition of 1888. He commanded the troops at the aotion of Kotkai, in connection with whioh he was mentioned in the despatches and received the medal with clasp. From 1882 to 1886 he was assistant adjatant and quartermaster general in Ireland and was then sent to India, where he commanded the seoond olass district for four years. From 1890 to 1895 he was adjatant general in India, and afterwards commanded the Q etta district for four years. On the expiration of this command he retired from active service in 1899. In 1896 he married a daughter of Lieutenant-General A. G. Hand- cook, C.B., I.3.C., whom he leaves a widow with two sons.

div.head: EGYPTOLOGICAL NOTES.
div.p: M. Maspero has published a report on his recent work of excavation and restoration in Egypt. An interesting discovery has been made at Karnak hy M. Legrain, whose name is well- known in the Egyptological world. It oonsists of a postern gate with a row of oynooephalæ, whose presence is easily acoounted for, as with the anoieut Egyptians the ape was always represented as a worshipper of the rising son. M. Barsanti intends restoring the Temple of Gonrnah at Thebes, before oompleting similar work on the reios at Edfoo (the Apollinopolis Magna of the Greeks, famous alike for its tem- ples and the antagonism of its antique inhabi- tants to the adoration of the orooodile.) Stelæ have been laid hare in the oourse of excavations at Bakkara, by M. Qiihell, and at Toukh and Gjrmons, Mr. Edgar has dag up the remainder of the treasure of gold-ornaments found last year. Far greater impirtanoe, however, attaobes to a veritable treasure trove at Korn Schgaon, which has been under M. Maspero's eye for several years. Here fifty rolls of beautiful manusoript, some mure than foar metres long, were found. Among these, M. Lefebre has identified title deeds, a will and codioil in Greek, and an unknown oomedy of Menander, of whioh there are 1,200 verses. We are glad to learn that M. Lefebre intends to publish these verses shortly. These fragments will enable ns to study Menander more direotly than by the interpre- tation of his Latin imitators.

La National Bank a réaotionoéde 1/8 à 27,3, v L’Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 9 7/8, de même que la Dairaà 17 et la Delta Light à 12.
A-Paris, l’action Crédit Fonoier Egyptien a haussé de 3 francs à 784. Lt Banque d’Athène\ est restée stationnaire à 145.

Un petit vent de réaotion a soufflé, ce matin, anr quelques devises de notre marché des valears. C’est là an fait naturel après 11 forts poussée de ces joars derniers, poussés opérée jaate an moment où la péanrie d’or locale était considérée comme an obstacle iu snrmontable à la hausse, voire comme on é’ément certain de baisse.

Or, maintenant que la tension monétaire diminue, il serait pent être téméraire de s’at tendre à une dépression sérieuse. Il se prednit, tout bonnement, an tassement rationnel, appelé à faire pins de bien qne de mal, en oe sens qa’il donnera da ressort an marohé et lai permettra de marcher aisément à la oon- quête de pins hauts ocurs, an far et à mesure que nous avancerons dans la saiBcn de affaires.

Aassi fandra-t-il peut-être surveiller les bonnes valeurs qni pourraient être le plos atteintes celles-là bénéficieront, à coup sûr, les premières, da mouvement qai succédera à celai qui s’est dessiné aujourd'hui.

Bref, en dépit de tontes les circonstance^ passagères défavorables qui peuvent se pro dnire, il reste évident que les bonnes tendances finiront par avoir le dessus : c’est la consé- quence fireéa de la prospérité générale du pays, augmentée par les prix inespérés anx qnels se vend le coton, prospérité qa’nne gêne éphémère ne sacrait, en auouo CM, affecter ou compromettre. Au reste, la clôture a été plus ferme.

div.head: WEIGHTS AND MEASURES.
div.p: ADOPTION OF METRIC SYSTEM.
London, October 17

A sensation has been caused in commercial circ’es owing to Mesara. Kynoch Limited having adopted the metric system for weights at,A measures. Sterling will be worked out to Kjur places of decimals, and be used as unit money for purposes of calculations.

Mr. Arthur Chamberlain, the chairman of Kynoch Limited, says that be supposes that the metric system will be some day compulsory. “We are merely anticipating by this means we are reducing the cost of our calculations and facilitate g our export trade.

div.head: THE LUTIN DISASTER.
div.p: NO HOPE FOR CREW.
PARIS, October 17.
The submarine Lutin, with fourteen men on board, has disappeared off Bizerta. Efforts have been made to recover it, but rough weather renders the task difficult. (Reuters)
TUNIS, October 17.
'Hie British Consol haa cabled to Malta for assistance to Taise the Latin, which lies at a depth of 125 feet.(Reuter)
BIZERTA, October 17
It is hoped that the Lutin may be refloated, hut the crew is believed to be lost. (Eavat)
PARIS, October 17.
M. Thomson has left for Bizerta.

div.head: AN AUDACIOUS THIEF
div.p: EXTRAORDINARY OCCURRENCE IN BERLIN.

An astounding robbery has taken place at Kcepenick, a suburb of the city. A man dressed as a captain stopped a squad of guardsmen who were returning from drill and ordered them to accompany him to Kcepenick. He entered the town-hall and arrested the Mayor and cashier and sent them under guard to the city. He seized £250 on the gTouud of a bogu Imperial order regarding municipal irregularities and ordered the guardsmen to remain in occupation of the town-ball. He then decamped in a motor oar. (Reuter)

div.head: LORD MAYOR IN PARIS.
div.p: KISSES THE MARKET QUEEN.
PARIS, October 17.

The Lord Mayor of London and the members of the Corporation drove to the Central Market, where they had a most enthusiastic reception. Bouquets were presented to the Lord Mayor, who thanked and kissed the Market Queen. (Reuter)

div.head: TURKEY AND PERSIA.
div.p: “SICK MAN” CLIMBS DOWN.
CONSTANTINOPLE, October 17.
As a result of the Persian Ambassador representations, instructions bave been sent to the Turkish boundary commissioner to proceed with the demarcation in a spirit of equity and justice. (Reuter)

div.head: REGENCY OF BRUNSWICK.
div.p: BERLIN, October 17.
Owing to the Emperor’s refusal to consider the Duke of Cumberland’s proposal, a bill has been introduced into the Brunswick Diet ordering the election of a new Regent.

div.head: AMERICA AND THE FAR EAST
div.p: NEW YORK, October 17. The Government has ordered fonr powerful armoared croisera to join the squadron in the Far East, in order to moie effectively protect American interests. (Reuter)

div.head: M SARKIEN’S HEALTH.
div.p: M Sarmn’a health will oblige him to resign. If he decides upon this ha will pat his resigna- tiou before the Connoil on Monday. (ETacot)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: (From OUR FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT.) London, Ootober l2.

In onr last artiole we referred to Egypt as ;he unknown factor in the money situation, tnd we forecasted that before this year’s cotton jrop conld be moved farther considerable quan- :ities of gold woald be required in Egypt. That Precast is proving correot. Daring the week £2,000.000 have left the Bank for abroad, the balk of which, say £1,600.000, has gone to Egypt, and £20,000 to Constantinople. As the ootton crop, we understand, promises to be bnmper both as regards qaantity and quality, there is every probability that still further quantities of gold will be required for Egypt. The more general opinion here seems to be that further £2,000.000 will be required for your market before all the demands are satisfied. Oa the other baud, a tew of the older and conservative members of the money market l to think that this amount is rather overstated than otherwise. The artioles on the money famine in Egypt contained in your issues of the 4th and 5th inst. have been read with muoh interest in this market, and have had a distinctly good effeot as showing the ability ot the Egyptian Govern- ment to come to the resoue in cases of need. It is perfectly true that the Egyptian demand has this year been rather heavy, but a comparison of this season’s demands with those of the past five years shows that it is hardly correot to describe this, as it has been by writers here, as "very abnormal,” in view of the incieased size of the orop, dne in a measure to the improvement of inigation, and the consequently larger area under cotton cultiva- tion. For the convenience of our readers we tabu- late these returns, which are as follows :—

It is obvious that with the marvellous pros perity whioh has followed the entry of Great Britain into Egypt larger gold demands are inevitable as the natural result of such pros perity, and this year an important faotor in the sitaation has been the high price of ootton and the heavy speculation in that commodity. The hesvy withdrawals this week and the increase of the Berlin Bank rate from 5 per cent, to 6 per cent, oompe’led the Direotors of the Bank of England at their meeting yester- day to take the unusual but pcrfeotly justifi able course of putting the rate up a fall point to 5 per cent., a rate we have n it seen sinoe 1901. It is oonfident'y expected that this will speedily prove effective in restoring the market to a normal condition. At the same time one cannot help feeding we are running on very short commons, and if the demand for Egypt continues to the extent above mentioned, to which must be added the great probability of increased requirements owing to the flourish ing condition of trade not only in this country but throughout the world, we nny be getting very near the lines ot a 6 per oent. rate before the Bank re erve can be brought back to a normal state. The Stock Exchange view of the 5 per oent rate seems to be one of relief, and they conse- quently look for better prioes in their markets in the near future, but as there is no chance of oheaper money, at all events, for the rest of this year, our opinion is that the higher rate of interest must affect gilt edged securities for some time to come. The Bank of the Netherlands yesterday raised its rate of disooant from 4 .^ per oent. to 5 per oeDt. and the Bank of Norway has to day increase! its rake from 5 percent, to 5^ per oent. The Bank return this week shows that, making allowance for a contraction of £394,000 in the circulation, the Reserve has dropped £2,112,000, bringing the total down to £IS.29O,00 The proportion to liabilities is 3 per cent, lower at 35.45 per cent.

The very cheerfnl tone which the stock markets have maintained this week under conditions whioh a few weeks ago would have oaased them to touch the lowest point of de pression has been viewed with satisfaction by members of the Stock Exohange, who not un reasonably argue that it markets can maintain suoh cheerfulness in the face of very adverse circumstances, a substantial revival may expected when conditions are more favourable That o'ream stances this week have been against anything in the shape of active business will be obvious when it is pointed out that not only bas anxiety regarding money diffi inities been'very marked, owing to heavy withdrawals from the Bank, the ucrease of the Berlin Bank rate, and, for the greater part r f the week anticipations of a substantial increase in the rate here, bat members have also been busily oocupiel in arranging the settlement. Never theles®, in spile of all, markets have per sistently refused to be adverse’y influenced and althoogh the amount of business done has naturally been limited, a fair qnantity of investment orders have been dealt with. The possibility of a five per oent. Punk rate had been discounted to the fu’lest possible extent, so that the effeot of the announcement1 upon markets was practically nil. Consols showed a slight easing-off, but in the main the ] changes were quite insignificant. | This morning business was confined to the concluding arrangement of the settlement. The tone has continued firm, and Consols early recovered yes1 erday’s loss.

The suspense regarding the action the Directors of the Bank of England might take yesterday, and the continued drain on the s'oek of gold, retarded movements in the gilt- edged market, bnt tha tone kept very steady. To day Consols have gained 4 at 86|, thus showing a slight advance on the week. Other gilt-edged stocks are fairly firm.

In the international market rnmonrs regard- ing the health of the Saltan again adversely affected Turkish stocks, and the Unified fell to 92$, bnt the price yesterday improved to 92J. They leave off to-night at 93. Russians, after the relapse last week end, reoovered to an appreciable extent, and the Fours leave off firm at 72$, and the soript of the new loan at 8^ disooant. With reference to the conversion of some of the Japanese issues, to which we have previously referred, Mr. K. Takahashi, the Japanese Financial Commissioner, who has now arrived in England, stated the other day in an interview that the Japanese Government now proposed to iseus a farther £25,000,000 for the conversion of the six per cent, foreign loans, bat it was impossible to say when this wonld be made. So far as he coaid see the present moment was not a favourable one for the operation. It only remained to watch the markets of the world and to seize the best opportunity that presented itself. Japanese stocks have been weak, and the changes are to lower levels.
Home Ralls.

The home railway market has a firm ap pearance, and it is satiefaotory to be able to say this of it after the recent aonte depression. There have been evidences cf moderate invest- ment demands, and yesterday some of the heavies, inolnding Berwiok*, Great Northern Deferred, Great Eastern, and the Scotch stocks, were especially favoured. The ohanges to-day have been slight
Americans.

On the whole the Ametioan market has been strong, and the increased Bank rate failed to check operations, bnt the tone to-day has been rather irregular. The downward movement in Aitchison shares, which followed the announcement of the dividend, has ceased, and the qnotation kept firm nntil to-day, bnt has now fallen away § to 107J. Union Paoifios have been well sap ported, and the price advanced to 196J, hat closes i lower at 196J-. Yesterday Chioago Milwaukee were a feature, and closed 2 np at 183. They close about this figure to-night, as oompared with 181J last Friday. Pennsyl vania have pot on 1| at 75.
Egyptians.

There has been a fair amount of activity in the Egyptian market Egyptian Estates yesterday came in for more attention than for some time past, and these show a considerable' improvement on the week at 2^, the Deferred at 13£. National Bauks have been alternately offered and bid for, and remain firm at 26|-$, while Agricultural Banks have veakened a fraction, at 9f. Land Banks are unchanged. New Egyptian continue firm a shade higher than last week at 1^ and Corporation of Western Egypt are about ^ higher at premium.
Mining.

The chief feature in the Sooth Afrioan market are Vaal River D amond shares. There was extensive baying of these yesterday, and the prioa sported sharply to 2J§ after opening at 1 the advance being dne to rnmonrs of an important discovery of diamonds on the oompany’s property. Premiers, on the other hand, were weak, and lost 1| at 12^. Chartered wore an aotive coanter, dosing bayers at 1^. Vaal Rivers leave off to-night | at 3$. a further rise of ff Premier at 12j, and Chartered 12/6 Rand Mines are 6
Egyptians.

Egyptian mining shares maiutain a firm appearance, bat there is very little business being done in them. Egyptian Mines are a shade higher at 4-., but Nile Valleys at 6»., Egyptian Options at lj, and United Africans at 1 18/32 are quite unchanged.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
